dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A massive data breach at Facebook, exposing Elon Musk and Bill Gates, and the stock still goes up more than 3%.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Shares of social media platform Twitter dropped more than 3% following a massive digital currency scam late on Wednesday: Hackers gained access to dozens of high-profile accounts, including Tesla CEO Elon Musk, former vice president Joe Biden and Microsoft cofounder Bill Gates.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that is just wild. And you know, the market overall was up too—the Dow was up over 150 points at the open.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 0.6%, over 150 points, at Thursdays open, while the S&P 500 fell 0.6% and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite lost 0.9%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and a lot of that seems tied to the jobless claims data. Only 300,000 fewer Americans filed for unemployment last week, which is better than expected.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Stocks fell after jobless claims data came in slightly worse than expected, with 1.3 million more Americans filing for unemployment in the week ending July 11, according to the Labor Department.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and retail sales jumped 1.5% in June, which is almost as strong as the month before. So there's some real optimism there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and retail sales jumped one point five percent in June, which is almost as strong as the month before. So there's some real optimism there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Retail sales jumped by 7.5% in Junehigher than the 5.2% expected, but lower than last months record surge of 17.7%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then you've got these mixed bank earnings. Bank of America missed estimates but still rose nearly 4% because of a $4 billion profit from pandemic investments.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you've got these mixed bank earnings. Bank of America missed estimates but still rose nearly four percent because of a four dollars billion profit from pandemic investments.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Bank of America topped estimates but its stock fell nearly 4% as the company set aside $4 billion for coronavirus-related losses.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, whereas Morgan Stanley fell almost 1% 'cause they narrowly missed expectations. Their fixed income trading revenue dropped 17%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, whereas Morgan Stanley fell almost one percent 'cause they narrowly missed expectations. Their fixed income trading revenue dropped seventeen percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Morgan Stanley shares rose by almost 1% after the bank easily beat analyst expectations thanks to surging trading revenueswith its revenue from fixed income traders increasing by 170% last quarter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's interesting how the market's reacting so differently to earnings misses this season.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's interesting how the market's reacting so differently to earnings misses this season.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Wednesday, stocks rallied on positive coronavirus vaccine news from Moderna and strong earnings results from Goldman Sachs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, so it's been a real rollercoaster week. But infections are actually decreasing—over 67,000 fewer cases reported earlier this week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, so it's been a real rollercoaster week. But infections are actually decreasing-over sixty seven thousand fewer cases reported earlier this week.

dialogue_turns.text: Which probably explains some of the renewed confidence. People are feeling like maybe we're turning a corner.

artist_script:
A massive data breach at Facebook, exposing Elon Musk and Bill Gates, and the stock still goes up more than 3%.
HostB: Yeah, that is just wild. And you know, the market overall was up too—the Dow was up over 150 points at the open.
HostA: Right, and a lot of that seems tied to the jobless claims data. Only 300,000 fewer Americans filed for unemployment last week, which is better than expected.
HostB: Exactly, and retail sales jumped 1.5% in June, which is almost as strong as the month before. So there’s some real optimism there.
HostA: But then you’ve got these mixed bank earnings. Bank of America missed estimates but still rose nearly 4% because of a $4 billion profit from pandemic investments.
HostB: Yeah, whereas Morgan Stanley fell almost 1% 'cause they narrowly missed expectations. Their fixed income trading revenue dropped 17%.
HostA: It’s interesting how the market’s reacting so differently to earnings misses this season.
HostB: For sure. And you know, this comes after a tough Wednesday with that Pfizer vaccine news and Goldman’s weak results.
HostA: Right, so it’s been a real rollercoaster week. But infections are actually decreasing—over 67,000 fewer cases reported earlier this week.
HostB: Which probably explains some of the renewed confidence. People are feeling like maybe we’re turning a corner.
HostA: Let’s hope so. Still, Facebook going up after a breach like that… that’s a head-scratcher.
HostB: Totally. The market works in mysterious ways sometimes.
